name: Prana
shortDescription: Vital life force energy that animates all living beings and pervades the cosmos
fullDescription: Prana (Sanskrit: ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£, literally 'breath' or 'life force') is the vital energy that animates all living beings and pervades the entire universe in Hindu and yogic philosophy. More than just breath, prana is the subtle life force that connects body, mind, and spirit, flowing through energy channels (nadis) and accumulating in energy centers (chakras). In the human body, prana manifests in five primary forms (pancha pranas): prana (upward energy in chest, breathing), apana (downward energy in lower abdomen, elimination), samana (digestive fire in navel area), udana (ascending energy in throat, speech), and vyana (pervading energy throughout body, circulation). At the cosmic level, prana is the universal energy that sustains all existence. Pranayama (breath control) is the yogic practice of regulating and directing prana to enhance vitality, calm the mind, and achieve higher states of consciousness. Mastery over prana is said to lead to extraordinary abilities and spiritual realization.

manifestations.description: Prana manifests as the five vital airs (pancha pranas) in the body, flows through 72,000 nadis (energy channels), and accumulates in the seven chakras. It is experienced as breath, vitality, and the subtle energy that animates consciousness.

mythologyContexts.usage: Prana is fundamental to yoga, Ayurveda, and tantric practices. In yoga, pranayama (breath control) is one of the eight limbs of Patanjali's system, used to purify the body, calm the mind, and prepare for meditation. Ayurveda works with prana to diagnose and treat diseases. Tantric practices manipulate prana through kundalini yoga, mantra, and visualization. The Upanishads identify prana as the connecting principle between the individual and cosmic reality. Understanding and controlling prana is essential for spiritual development.

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Prana symbolizes the bridge between matter and spirit, the animating principle that makes life possible. Breath as prana represents the continuous exchange between individual and cosmos - we breathe in universal prana and breathe out personal energies. The five pranas symbolize the different functional aspects of life force. Prana's flow through nadis represents the interconnection of all bodily and mental functions. The regulation of prana through pranayama symbolizes the yogi's mastery over life itself, transcending ordinary limitations. Prana as both individual and cosmic represents the microcosm-macrocosm relationship central to Hindu thought.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Prana is central to multiple Indian traditions - yoga, Ayurveda, martial arts, and spiritual practices. Pranayama is practiced daily by millions for health, mental clarity, and spiritual development. The concept parallels similar ideas in other cultures: chi (Chinese), ki (Japanese), pneuma (Greek), ruach (Hebrew). Modern research on breath and physiology has validated some claims about breath control's effects on nervous system, stress, and health. The concept of prana has entered global wellness culture through yoga's worldwide spread. Understanding prana provides a framework for holistic health integrating body, breath, mind, and spirit.
